Caesarea-Maritima.org Chronology: This chronology is adapted from the chronology used in The New Encyclopedia of Archaeological Excavations in the Holy Land
. This taxonomy is used in the catRef encoding to classify the testimonia according to the time period(s) of the events described, rather than the date of composition of the testimonium. For example, Josephus may describe events occuring well before the period of his writing.
Caesarea-Maritima.org Testimonia Typology: This typology defines three subsets of testimonia employed by the project and is used in the catRef below to further categorize a given testimonia record.

category.catDesc: A "direct testimonium" contains a word or phrase that is a direct reference to, or name for, the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. When a "direct testimonium" also contains indirect references, the classification by type is nevertheless marked only as "direct".

An "indirect testimonium" makes only an indirect reference to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. This indirect reference may take the form of a common noun or may be implied by context.

A "toponymic testimonium" contains a toponymic epithet related to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs. When a "direct testimonium" also contain a "toponymic testimonium", the testimonium is marked as belonging to both types. These two types do not always overlap and thus our data set also includes "toponymic testimonia" which are not "direct testimonia".

profileDesc.creation: This entry is taken from Church History 4.27.1-4.27.8 written by Socrates of Constantinople in ca. 439-450 C.E.. This work was likely written in Constantinople.

body.desc: τῇ Καισαρείᾳ, and Caesarea are directly attested at Socrates of Constantinople, Church History 4.27.1-4.27.8. This passage was written ca. ca. 439-450 C.E. possibly in Constantinople.

Socrates of Constantinople, the “Scholastic,” was an otherwise unknown historian of the early 5th century. He wrote his account of the Church from 305 to 439 to continue Eusebius of Caesarea, adopting a particular perspective on the relationship between Imperial and ecclesiastical authority. In this passage, Socrates surveys the career of Gregory “the Miracle-Worker” from Neocaesarea in Pontus, who studied philosophy under Origen at Caesarea.
body.ab:
(1) Ἐπειδὴ δέ τινες ἐκ τῆς ὁμωνυμίας πλανῶνται {καὶ ἐκ τῶν ἐπιγραφομένων Γρηγορίου βιβλίων}, δεῖ εἰδέναι ὅτι ἄλλος ἐστὶν ὁ Ποντικὸς Γρηγόριος, ὅστις ἐκ τῆς ἐν Πόντῳ Νεοκαισαρείας ὁρμώμενος ἀρχαιότερος τούτων ἐστίν· μαθητὴς γὰρ Ὠριγένους ἐγένετο. (2) Περὶ τούτου τοῦ Γρηγορίου πολὺς ὁ λόγος ἔν τε Ἀθήναις καὶ Βηρυτῷ καὶ ὅλῃ τῇ Ποντικῇ διοικήσει, ὡς δὲ εἰπεῖν καὶ πάσῃ τῇ οἰκουμένῃ. (3) Οὗτος γὰρ ὡς τῶν Ἀθήνῃσι παιδευτηρίων ἀναχωρήσας ἐν τῇ Βηρυτῷ νόμους ἐμάνθανεν, πυθόμενος {τε} ἐν τῇ Καισαρείᾳ τὰ ἱερὰ γράμματα ἑρμηνεύειν Ὠριγένην, δρομαῖος ἐπὶ τὴν Καισάρειαν παραγίνεται. (4) Ἀκροασάμενός τε τῆς μεγαλοφώνου θεωρίας τῶν ἱερῶν γραμμάτων, πολλὰ χαίρειν εἰπὼν τοῖς Ῥωμαϊκοῖς νόμοις ἀχώριστος ἦν τοῦ λοιποῦ, καὶ ὑπ’ αὐτοῦ παιδευθεὶς τὴν ἀληθῆ φιλοσοφίαν {καὶ} μετὰ ταῦτα ἐπὶ τὴν πατρίδα τῶν γονέων καλεσάντων ἀνεχώρησε. (5) Κἀκεῖ πρῶτον μὲν λαϊκὸς ὢν πολλὰ σημεῖα ἐποίησεν, νοσοῦντας θεραπεύων καὶ δαίμονας δι’ ἐπιστολῶν φυγαδεύων καὶ τοὺς ἑλληνίζοντας τοῖς τε λόγοις καὶ πλέον τοῖς γινομένοις ὑπ’ αὐτοῦ προσαγόμενος. (6) Μέμνηται δὲ αὐτοῦ καὶ Πάμφιλος ὁ μάρτυς <καὶ Εὐσέβιος ὁ τούτου ἐπώνυμος> ἐν τοῖς περὶ Ὠριγένους πονηθεῖσιν αὐτοῖς βιβλίοις, ἐν οἷς καὶ συντακτικὸς λόγος Γρηγορίου εἰς Ὠριγένην παράκειται. (7) Γεγόνασιν οὖν, ὡς ἐν κεφαλαίῳ εἰπεῖν, <τρεῖς> Γρηγόριοι, ὅ τε ἀρχαῖος οὗτος καὶ μαθητὴς Ὠριγένους, καὶ ὁ Ναζιανζηνὸς καὶ ὁ ἀδελφὸς Βασιλείου. (8) Ἐγένετο δὲ καὶ ἄλλος Γρηγόριος ἐν Ἀλεξανδρείᾳ, ὃν οἱ Ἀρειανοὶ κατὰ τὸν καιρὸν τῆς φυγῆς Ἀθανασίου κατέστησαν.
Ed. Hussey and Bright 1893 with ref. to Hansen 1995 Hansen inserted the reference to Eusebius (<καὶ Εὐσέβιος ὁ τούτου ἐπώνυμος>, §6) from the Armenian and Syriac texts; Perichon and Maraval 2004-2007, vol. 3, p. 116 n. 1.

(1) But since some people are confused by the similarity of the name and by the books bearing the name Gregory on the cover, it is important to notice that Gregory of Pontus is a different person (from Gregory of Nazianzus). Originally from Neocaesarea in Pontus, he was of an earlier generation than the ones (already discussed), for he was a student of Origen. (2) This Gregory’s fame was great in Athens, at Berytus, throughout the entire diocese of Pontus, and one might say in the whole world. (3) When he had left the schools in Athens and was studying law at Berytus, he learned that Origen was interpreting the Holy Scriptures at Caesarea and hastened there. (4) When Gregory had heard his viewpoint on the Holy Scriptures expressed with such great eloquence, he said a final farewell to Roman Law and henceforth was inseparable (from Origen). He studied true philosophy under him, and later departed (Caesarea) when his parents called him back to his homeland. (5) There for the first time, while a layman, he performed many miracles, healing the sick, driving out demons through his letters, and bringing pagans under his influence through his words and especially through his deeds. (6) Pamphilus the martyr <and Eusebius who is named after him> mention him in the works they wrote about Origen, to which is added the Gregory’s farewell speech to Origen. (7) There were then, to summarize, three Gregories: the first and earliest was the student of Origen; the second was the bishop of Nazianzus; the third was Basil’s brother. There was another Gregory in Alexandria, whom the Arians installed as bishop during the exile of Athanasius.
Adapted from Zenos 1890 and Périchon and Maraval 2004-2007
